Green, Quantized Federated Learning over Wireless Networks: An Energy-Efficient Design

Minsu Kim, Walid Saad, Fellow, IEEE, Mohammad Mozaffari, Member IEEE, and Merouane Debbah, Fellow, IEEE
M. Kim and W. Saad are with the Wireless@VT Group, Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Virginia Tech, Arlington, VA, USA (email: {msukim, walids}@vt.edu.) M. Mozaffari is with Ericsson Research, Santa Clara, CA, USA (email: mohammad.mozaffari@ericsson.com). M. Debbah is with Khalifa University of Science and Technology, Abu Dhabi, UAE (email: merouane.debbah@ku.ac.ae). A preliminary version of this work was presented at IEEE ICC 2022 [1]. This research was supported by the U.S. National Science Foundation under Grant CNS-2114267. The implementation code is available on https://github.com/news-vt
Abstract

The practical deployment of federated learning (FL) over wireless networks requires balancing energy efficiency, convergence rate, and a target accuracy due to the limited available resources of devices. Prior art on FL often trains deep neural networks (DNNs) to achieve high accuracy and fast convergence using 32 bits of precision level. However, such scenarios will be impractical for resource-constrained devices since DNNs typically have high computational complexity and memory requirements. Thus, there is a need to reduce the precision level in DNNs to reduce the energy expenditure. In this paper, a green-quantized FL framework, which represents data with a finite precision level in both local training and uplink transmission, is proposed. Here, the finite precision level is captured through the use of quantized neural networks (QNNs) that quantize weights and activations in fixed-precision format. In the considered FL model, each device trains its QNN and transmits a quantized training result to the base station. Energy models for the local training and the transmission with quantization are rigorously derived. To minimize the energy consumption and the number of communication rounds simultaneously, a multi-objective optimization problem is formulated with respect to the number of local iterations, the number of selected devices, and the precision levels for both local training and transmission while ensuring convergence under a target accuracy constraint. To solve this problem, the convergence rate of the proposed FL system is analytically derived with respect to the system control variables. Then, the Pareto boundary of the problem is characterized to provide efficient solutions using the normal boundary inspection method. Design insights on balancing the tradeoff between the two objectives while achieving a target accuracy are drawn from using the Nash bargaining solution and analyzing the derived convergence rate. Simulation results show that the proposed FL framework can reduce energy consumption until convergence by up to 70% compared to a baseline FL algorithm that represents data with full precision without damaging the convergence rate.

I Introduction

\Ac

FL is an emerging paradigm that enables distributed learning among wireless devices [2]. In federated learning (FL), a central server (e.g., a base station (BS)) and multiple mobile devices collaborate to train a shared machine learning model without sharing raw data. Many FL works employ deep neural networks, whose size constantly grows to match the increasing demand for higher accuracy [3]. Such DNN architectures can have tens of millions of parameters and billions of multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations. Moreover, to achieve fast convergence, these networks typically represent data in 32 bits of full precision level, which may consume significant energy due to high computational complexity and memory requirements [4]. Additionally, a large DNN can induce a significant communication overhead [5]. Under such practical constraints, it may be challenging to deploy FL over resource-constrained Internet of Things (IoT) devices due to its large energy cost. To design an energy-efficient, green FL scheme, one can reduce the precision level to decrease the energy consumption during the local training and communication phase. However, a low precision level can jeopardize the convergence rate by introducing quantization errors. Therefore, finding the optimal precision level that balances energy efficiency and convergence rate while meeting desired FL accuracy constraints will be a major challenge for the practical deployment of green FL over wireless networks.

Several works have studied the energy efficiency of FL from a system-level perspective [6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11]. The work in [6] investigated the energy efficiency of FL algorithms in terms of the carbon footprint compared to centralized learning. In [7], the authors formulated a joint minimization problem for energy consumption and training time by optimizing heterogeneous computing and wireless resources. The work in [8] developed an approach to minimize the total energy consumption by controlling a target accuracy during local training based on a derived convergence rate. The authors in [9] proposed a sum energy minimization problem by considering joint bandwidth and workload allocation of heterogeneous devices. In [10], the authors studied a joint optimization problem to minimize the energy and the training time under a target accuracy. The work in [11] developed a resource management scheme by leveraging the information of loss functions of each device to maximize the accuracy under constrained communication and computation resources. However, these works [6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11] did not consider the energy efficiency of their DNN structure during training. Since mobile devices have limited computing and memory resources, deploying an energy-efficient DNN will be necessary for green FL.

To further improve FL energy efficiency, model compression methods such as quantization were studied in [12, 13, 14, 15]. In [12], the authors developed an over-the-air FL system that uses one-bit gradient quantization aggregation scheme. The authors in [13] developed an approach to minimize the training time by optimizing transmission precision level and bandwidth allocation. The work in [14] proposed an approach to minimize the energy consumption and the loss function by optimizing model compression design for uplink transmission and device selection strategy. In [15], the authors studied an energy minimization problem by controlling local iterations, bandwidth allocation, and precision level for both local training and transmission under full device participation scheme. However, the works in [12, 13, 14] only considered the communication efficiency while there can be a large energy consumption in local training due to high precision level. Although the work in [15] considered quantization for both local training and transmission, it used full device participation scheme, which is not practical due to stragglers, and only the energy consumption is minimized. In our previous work [1], an energy minimization problem was formulated to investigate the tradeoff between energy, precision, and accuracy. However, the same precision level was used for local training and transmission as done in [15]. As such, the results of [1] cannot be directly applied for more general cases such as those with heterogeneous devices and non-i.i.d datasets. Moreover, the number of local iterations and the number of selected devices were not jointly optimized. To the best of our knowledge, there are no current works that jointly consider the tradeoff between energy efficiency, convergence rate, and accuracy while simultaneously controlling local iterations, the number of scheduled devices, and precision levels in local training and transmission for green FL over wireless networks.

The main contribution of this paper is a novel green, energy-efficient quantized FL framework that can represent data with a finite precision level in both local training and uplink transmission. Our contributions include:

  • •

    We propose an FL framework that takes into account stochastic quantization in both local training and transmission with different precision levels. All devices train their quantized neural networks, whose weights and activations are quantized with a finite precision level, so as to decrease energy consumption for computation and memory access. In uplink communication, each device performs quantization to its training result to improve the communication efficiency.

  • •

    To quantify the energy consumption, we propose a rigorous energy model for the local training based on the physical structure of a processing chip. We also derive the energy model for the uplink transmission with quantization. Although a low precision level can save the energy consumption per iteration, it decreases the convergence rate because of quantization errors. Thus, there is a need for a new approach to analyze the tradeoff between energy efficiency, convergence rate, and target accuracy by optimizing the precision levels. To this end, we formulate a novel multi-objective optimization problem by controlling the precision levels to jointly minimize the total energy consumption and the number of communication rounds while ensuring convergence with a target accuracy. We also incorporate two additional control variables: the number of local iterations and the number of selected devices at each communication round, which have a significant impact on both the energy consumption and the convergence time.

  • •

    To solve this problem, we first analytically derive the convergence rate of our FL framework with respect to the control variables under non-iid data distribution. We then optimize sampling probabilities for devices based on the derived convergence rate. Subsequently, we use the normal boundary inspection (NBI) method to obtain the Pareto boundary of our multi-objective optimization problem. To balance the tradeoff between the two objectives, we present and analyze two practical operating points: the Nash bargaining solution (NBS) and the sum minimizing solution (SUM) points.

  • •

    Based on the aforementioned operating points and the derived convergence rate, we provide design insights into the proposed FL framework. For instance, the total energy consumption initially decreases as the precision levels increase, however, after a certain threshold, a higher precision will induce higher energy costs. Meanwhile, the convergence rate will always improve with a higher precision. However, this improvement becomes negligible after a certain level. We also show that we need a higher precision level to achieve higher target accuracy at the expense of more energy and communication rounds. We then provide the impacts of system parameters such as the number of devices and model size on the performance of the proposed FL.

Simulation results show that our FL model can reduce the energy consumption around 70% compared to FedAvg without damaging the convergence rate.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the system model. In Section III, we describe the studied problem. Section IV provides simulation results. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section V.

II System Model

where D=∑k=1NDk𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝐷𝑘D=\sum_{k=1}^{N}D_{k} is the total size of the entire dataset 𝒟=∪k=1N𝒟k𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}=\cup_{k=1}^{N}\mathcal{D}_{k}. Without loss of generality, we assume datasets across devices are non-iid.

Solving problem (2) typically requires an iterative process between the BS and devices. However, in practical systems, such as IoT systems, these devices are resource-constrained, particularly when it comes to computing and energy. Hence, we propose to manage the precision level of parameters used in our FL algorithm to reduce the energy consumption for computation, memory access, and transmission. As such, we adopt a QNN architecture whose weights and activations are quantized in fixed-point format rather than conventional 32-bit floating-point format [16]. During the training time, a QNN can reduce the energy consumption for MAC operation and memory access due to quantized weights and activations.

II-A Quantized Neural Networks

In our model, each device trains a QNN of identical structure using n𝑛n bits for quantization. High precision can be achieved if we increase n𝑛n at the cost of more energy usage. We can represent any given number in a fixed-point format such as [Ω.Φ]delimited-[]formulae-sequenceΩΦ[\Omega.\Phi], where ΩΩ\Omega is the integer part and ΦΦ\Phi is the fractional part of the given number [17]. Here, we use one bit to represent the integer part and (n−1)𝑛1(n-1) bits for the fractional part. Then, the smallest positive number that we can present is κ=2−n+1𝜅superscript2𝑛1\kappa=2^{-n+1}, and the possible range of numbers with n𝑛n bits will be [−1,1−2−n+1]11superscript2𝑛1[-1,1-2^{-n+1}]. Note that a QNN restricts the value of weights to [-1, 1]. Otherwise, weights can be very large without meaningful impact on the performance. We consider a stochastic quantization scheme [17] since it generally performs better than deterministic quantization [18]. Any given number w∈𝒘𝑤𝒘w\in\boldsymbol{w} can be stochastically quantized as follows:

Q​(w)={⌊w⌋,with probability⌊w⌋+κ−wκ,⌊w⌋+κ,with probabilityw−⌊w⌋κ,𝑄𝑤cases𝑤with probability𝑤𝜅𝑤𝜅𝑤𝜅with probability𝑤𝑤𝜅\displaystyle Q(w)=\begin{cases}\lfloor w\rfloor,&\quad\text{with probability}\quad\frac{\lfloor w\rfloor+\kappa-w}{\kappa},\\ \lfloor w\rfloor+\kappa,&\quad\text{with probability}\quad\frac{w-\lfloor w\rfloor}{\kappa},\end{cases} (3)

where ⌊w⌋𝑤\lfloor w\rfloor is the largest integer multiple of κ𝜅\kappa less than or equal to w𝑤w. In the following lemma, we analyze the features of the stochastic quantization.

Lemma 1.

For the stochastic quantization Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot), a scalar w𝑤w, and a vector 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

Proof.

We first derive 𝔼​[Q​(w)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑄𝑤\mathbb{E}[Q(w)] as

𝔼​[(Q​(w)−w)2]𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑄𝑤𝑤2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[(Q(w)-w)^{2}] =(⌊w⌋−w)2​⌊w⌋+κ−wκ+(⌊w⌋+κ−w)2​w−⌊w⌋κabsentsuperscript𝑤𝑤2𝑤𝜅𝑤𝜅superscript𝑤𝜅𝑤2𝑤𝑤𝜅\displaystyle=(\lfloor w\rfloor-w)^{2}\frac{\lfloor w\rfloor+\kappa-w}{\kappa}+(\lfloor w\rfloor+\kappa-w)^{2}\frac{w-\lfloor w\rfloor}{\kappa}

where (7) follows from the arithmetic mean and geometric mean inequality. Since expectation is a linear operator, we have 𝔼​[Q​(𝒘)]=𝒘𝔼delimited-[]𝑄𝒘𝒘\mathbb{E}[Q(\boldsymbol{w})]=\boldsymbol{w} from (6). From the definition of the square norm, 𝔼​[‖Q​(𝒘)−𝒘‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑄𝒘𝒘2\mathbb{E}[||Q(\boldsymbol{w})-\boldsymbol{w}||^{2}] can obtained as

∎

From Lemma 1, we can see that our quantization scheme is unbiased as its expectation is zero. However, the quantization error can still increase for a large model.

For device k𝑘k, we denote the quantized weights of layer l𝑙l as 𝒘(l)Q,k=Q​(𝒘(l)k)subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑄𝑘𝑙𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑙\boldsymbol{w}^{Q,k}_{(l)}=Q(\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{(l)}), where 𝒘(l)ksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑙\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{(l)} is the parameters of layer l𝑙l. Then, the output of layer l𝑙l will be: o(l)=g(l)​(𝒘(l)Q,k,o(l−1)),subscript𝑜𝑙subscript𝑔𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑄𝑘𝑙subscript𝑜𝑙1o_{(l)}=g_{(l)}(\boldsymbol{w}^{Q,k}_{(l)},o_{(l-1)}), where o(l−1)subscript𝑜𝑙1o_{(l-1)} is the output from the previous layer l−1𝑙1l-1, and g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) is the operation of layer l𝑙l on the input, including the linear sum of 𝒘(l)Q,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑄𝑘𝑙\boldsymbol{w}^{Q,k}_{(l)} and o(l−1)subscript𝑜𝑙1o_{(l-1)}, batch normalization, and activation. Note that our activation includes the stochastic quantization after a normal activation function such as ReLU. Then, the output of layer l𝑙l, i.e., o(l)subscript𝑜𝑙o_{(l)}, is fed into the next layer as an input. For training, we use the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm as follows

𝒘τ+1k←𝒘τk−η​∇Fk​(𝒘τQ,k,ξτk),←subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝜏1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝜏𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑄𝑘𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝜏\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{\tau+1}\leftarrow\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{\tau}-\eta\nabla F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{Q,k}_{\tau},\xi^{k}_{\tau}), (9)

where τ=1​…​I𝜏1…𝐼\tau=1\dots I is training iteration, η𝜂\eta is the learning rate, and ξ𝜉\xi is a sample from Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} for the current update. The update of weights is done in full precision so that stochastic gradient (SG) noise can be averaged out properly [16]. Then, we restrict the values of 𝒘τ+1ksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝜏1\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{\tau+1} to [−1,1]11[-1,1] as 𝒘τ+1k←clip​(𝒘τ+1k,−1,1)←subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝜏1clipsubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝜏111\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{\tau+1}\leftarrow\text{clip}(\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{\tau+1},-1,1) where clip​(⋅,−1,1)clip⋅11\text{clip}(\cdot,-1,1) projects an input to 1 if it is larger than 1, and projects an input to -1 if it is smaller than -1. Otherwise, it returns the same value as the input. Otherwise, 𝒘τ+1ksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝜏1\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{\tau+1} can become significantly large without a meaningful impact on quantization [16]. After each training, 𝒘τ+1ksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝜏1\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{\tau+1} will be quantized as 𝒘τ+1Q,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑄𝑘𝜏1\boldsymbol{w}^{Q,k}_{\tau+1} for the forward propagation.

II-B FL model

For learning, without loss of generality, we adopt FedAvg [4] to solve problem (2). At each communication round t𝑡t, the BS selects K𝐾K devices according to probability pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} for device k𝑘k such that ∑k=1Npk=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘1\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}=1, and we denote the sampled set as 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t}. The BS transmits the current global model 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{t} to the scheduled devices. Each device in 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t} trains its local model based on the received global model by running I𝐼I steps of SGD as below

𝒘t,τk=𝒘t,τ−1k−ηt​∇Fk​(𝒘t,τ−1Q,k,ξτk),∀τ=1,…,I,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝜏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝜏1𝑘subscript𝜂𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑄𝑘𝑡𝜏1subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝜏for-all𝜏1…𝐼\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}_{t,\tau}^{k}=\boldsymbol{w}_{t,\tau-1}^{k}-\eta_{t}\nabla F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{Q,k}_{t,\tau-1},\xi^{k}_{\tau}),\forall\tau=1,\dots,I, (10)

where ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} is the learning rate at communication round t𝑡t. Note that unscheduled devices do not perform local training. Then, each device in 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t} calculates the model update 𝒅t+1k=𝒘t+1k−𝒘tksubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑘𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{d}^{k}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t}, where 𝒘t+1k=𝒘t,I−1ksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡𝐼1\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t,I-1} and 𝒘tk=𝒘t,0ksubscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡0\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t}=\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t,0} [19]. Typically, 𝒅t+1ksubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑘𝑡1\boldsymbol{d}^{k}_{t+1} has millions of elements for DNN. It is not practical to send 𝒅t+1ksubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑘𝑡1\boldsymbol{d}^{k}_{t+1} with full precision for energy-constrained devices. Hence, we apply the same quantization scheme used in QNNs to 𝒅t+1ksubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑘𝑡1\boldsymbol{d}^{k}_{t+1} by denoting its quantized equivalent as 𝒅t+1Q,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑄𝑘𝑡1\boldsymbol{d}^{Q,k}_{t+1} with precision level m𝑚m. Thus, each device in 𝒩tsubscript𝒩𝑡\mathcal{N}_{t} clips its model update 𝒅t+1ksubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑘𝑡1\boldsymbol{d}^{k}_{t+1} using clip​(⋅)clip⋅\text{clip}(\cdot) to match the quantization range and transmits its quantized version to the BS. The received model updates are averaged by the BS, and the next global model 𝒘t+1subscript𝒘𝑡1\boldsymbol{w}_{t+1} will be generated as below

𝒘t+1=𝒘t+1K​∑k∈𝒩t+1𝒅t+1Q,k.subscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑘subscript𝒩𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑄𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{w}_{t}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{t+1}}\boldsymbol{d}^{Q,k}_{t+1}. (11)

The FL system repeats this process until the global loss function converges to a target accuracy constraint ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. We summarize this algorithm in Algorithm 1. Next, we propose the energy model for the computation and the transmission of our FL system.

II-C Computing and Transmission model

II-C1 Computing model

We consider a typical two-dimensional processing chip for convolutional neural networks as shown in Fig. 2 [5]. This chip has a DRAM, a parallel neuron array with p𝑝p MAC units, and two memory levels: a main SRAM buffer that stores the weights and activations and a local buffer that caches currently used weights and activations. Since the main SRAM buffer has a limited size, the input dataset is stored in the DRAM. Some weights can also be stored in the DRAM, if the whole weights cannot be fit in the main SRAM buffer. We use the MAC operation energy model of [20] whereby EMAC​(n)=A​(n/nmax)αsubscript𝐸MAC𝑛𝐴superscript𝑛subscript𝑛max𝛼E_{\text{MAC}}(n)=A\left(n/n_{\text{max}}\right)^{\alpha} for precision level n𝑛n, where A>0𝐴0A>0, 1<α<21𝛼21<\alpha<2, and nmaxsubscript𝑛maxn_{\text{max}} is the maximum precision level. Here, a MAC operation includes neuron output calculation, batch normalization, activation, and back-propagation. From [20], the energy consumption for accessing a local buffer can be modeled as EMAC​(n)subscript𝐸MAC𝑛E_{\text{MAC}}(n), and the energy for accessing a main buffer can be given by Em​(n)=2​EMAC​(n)subscript𝐸m𝑛2subscript𝐸MAC𝑛E_{\text{m}}(n)=2E_{\text{MAC}}(n). The energy consumption to access a DRAM can be modeled as ED​(n)=Ad​EMAC​(n)subscript𝐸D𝑛subscript𝐴𝑑subscript𝐸MAC𝑛E_{\text{D}}(n)=A_{d}E_{\text{MAC}}(n), where Ad>>1much-greater-thansubscript𝐴𝑑1A_{d}>>1. [5].

The energy consumption of device k𝑘k for doing inference (i.e., forward propagation) is Einfk​(n)subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑘inf𝑛E^{k}_{\text{inf}}(n) when n𝑛n bits are used for the quantization. Then, Einfk​(n)subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑘inf𝑛E^{k}_{\text{inf}}(n) is the sum of the computing energy EC​(n)subscript𝐸C𝑛E_{\text{C}}(n), the access energy for fetching weights from the buffers EW​(n)subscript𝐸W𝑛E_{\text{W}}(n), the access energy for fetching activations from the buffers EA​(n)subscript𝐸A𝑛E_{\text{A}}(n) and the access energy for fetching input features and weights from the DRAM EDRAM​(n)subscript𝐸DRAM𝑛E_{\text{DRAM}}(n), as follows [20]:

Einfk​(n)=EC​(n)+EW​(n)+EA​(n)+EDRAM​(n),subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑘inf𝑛subscript𝐸C𝑛subscript𝐸W𝑛subscript𝐸A𝑛subscript𝐸DRAM𝑛\displaystyle E^{k}_{\text{inf}}(n)=E_{\text{C}}(n)+E_{\text{W}}(n)+E_{\text{A}}(n)+E_{\text{DRAM}}(n),
EC​(n)=EMAC​(n)​Nc+2​Oc​EMAC​(nmax),subscript𝐸C𝑛subscript𝐸MAC𝑛subscript𝑁𝑐2subscript𝑂𝑐subscript𝐸MACsubscript𝑛max\displaystyle E_{\text{C}}(n)=E_{\text{MAC}}(n)\text{$N_{c}$}+2\text{$O_{c}$}\ E_{\text{MAC}}(n_{\text{max}}),
EW​(n)=Em​(n)​d+EMAC​(n)​Nc​n/p​nmax,subscript𝐸W𝑛subscript𝐸m𝑛𝑑subscript𝐸MAC𝑛subscript𝑁𝑐𝑛𝑝subscript𝑛max\displaystyle E_{\text{W}}(n)=E_{\text{m}}(n)d+E_{\text{MAC}}(n)\text{$N_{c}$}\sqrt{{n}/{pn_{\text{max}}}},
EA​(n)=2​Em​(n)​Oc+EMAC​(n)​Nc​n/p​nmax,subscript𝐸A𝑛2subscript𝐸m𝑛subscript𝑂𝑐subscript𝐸MAC𝑛subscript𝑁𝑐𝑛𝑝subscript𝑛max\displaystyle E_{\text{A}}(n)=2E_{\text{m}}(n)\text{$O_{c}$}+E_{\text{MAC}}(n)\text{$N_{c}$}\sqrt{{n}/{pn_{\text{max}}}},
EDRAM​(n)=ED​(nmax)​xin+2​ED​(n)​max⁡(d​n+Oc​n−S,0),subscript𝐸DRAM𝑛subscript𝐸Dsubscript𝑛maxsubscript𝑥in2subscript𝐸D𝑛𝑑𝑛subscript𝑂𝑐𝑛𝑆0\displaystyle E_{\text{DRAM}}(n)=E_{\text{D}}(n_{\text{max}})x_{\text{in}}+2E_{\text{D}}(n)\max(dn+\text{$O_{c}$}n-S,0), (12)

where Ncsubscript𝑁𝑐N_{c} is the number of MAC operations, d𝑑d is the number of weights, Ocsubscript𝑂𝑐O_{c} is the number of intermediate outputs in the network, xinsubscript𝑥inx_{\text{in}} is the input dimension, and S𝑆S is the size of the main SRAM buffer. For EC​(n)subscript𝐸C𝑛E_{\text{C}}(n), in a QNN, batch normalization and activation are done in full-precision nmaxsubscript𝑛maxn_{\text{max}} to each output [16]. We store quantized weights and activations in the SRAM main buffer. Once we fetch weights from a main to a local buffer, they can be reused in the local buffer afterward as shown in EW​(n)subscript𝐸W𝑛E_{\text{W}}(n). In Fig. 2, a MAC unit fetches weights from a local buffer to do computation. Since we are using a two-dimensional MAC array of p𝑝p MAC units, they can share fetched weights with the same row and column, which has p𝑝\sqrt{p} MAC units respectively. In addition, a MAC unit can fetch more weights due to the n𝑛n bits quantization compared with when weights are represented in nmaxsubscript𝑛maxn_{\text{max}} bits. Thus, we can reduce the energy consumption to access a local buffer by the amount of n/p​nmax𝑛𝑝subscript𝑛max\sqrt{{n}/{pn_{\text{max}}}}. A similar process applies to EA​(n)subscript𝐸A𝑛E_{\text{A}}(n) since activations are fetched from the main buffer and should be saved back to it for the calculation in the next layer. For EDRAM​(n)subscript𝐸DRAM𝑛E_{\text{DRAM}}(n), input features are processed in full-precision, and weights that cannot be stored in the SRAM will be fetched and stored to the DRAM.

As introduced in Section II-A, we calculate gradients in full-precision to average out the noise from SGD. In back-propagation, each layer calculates the gradients of its weights and the gradients of the activations of the previous layer. Hence, we can approximate the number of MAC operations as 2​Nc2subscript𝑁𝑐2\text{$N_{c}$} as done in [21]. Then, the energy consumption for back-propagation is

Ebacksubscript𝐸back\displaystyle E_{\text{back}} =2​Nc​EMAC​(nmax)+2​Em​(nmax)​Oc+Em​(nmax)​dabsent2subscript𝑁𝑐subscript𝐸MACsubscript𝑛max2subscript𝐸msubscript𝑛maxsubscript𝑂𝑐subscript𝐸msubscript𝑛max𝑑\displaystyle=2\text{$N_{c}$}E_{\text{MAC}}(n_{\text{max}})+2E_{\text{m}}(n_{\text{max}})\text{$O_{c}$}+E_{\text{m}}(n_{\text{max}})d
+2​EMAC​(nmax)​Nc​1p2subscript𝐸MACsubscript𝑛maxsubscript𝑁𝑐1𝑝\displaystyle\quad+2E_{\text{MAC}}(n_{\text{max}})\text{$N_{c}$}\sqrt{\frac{1}{p}}
+2​ED​(nmax)​max⁡(d​nmax+Oc​nmax−sm,0).2subscript𝐸Dsubscript𝑛max𝑑subscript𝑛maxsubscript𝑂𝑐subscript𝑛maxsubscript𝑠𝑚0\displaystyle\quad+2E_{\text{D}}(n_{\text{max}})\max(dn_{\text{max}}+O_{c}n_{\text{max}}-s_{m},0). (13)

Since back-propagation is done in full-precision, weights must first be fetched from the DRAM. Then, we fetch weights from the main buffer to the local buffer. The neuron MAC array proceeds with the calculation by fetching the cached weights and activations from the local buffer. Therefore, the energy consumption for one iteration of device k𝑘k is given by

EC,k​(n)=Einfk​(n)+Eback,k∈{1,…,N}.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐸𝐶𝑘𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑘inf𝑛subscript𝐸back𝑘1…𝑁\displaystyle E^{C,k}(n)=E^{k}_{\text{inf}}(n)+E_{\text{back}},\ k\in\{1,\dots,N\}. (14)

II-C2 Transmission Model

We use the orthogonal frequency domain multiple access (OFDMA) to transmit model updates to the BS. Each device occupies one resource block. The achievable rate of device k𝑘k will be:

rk=B​log2⁡(1+Pktx​h¯kN0​B),subscript𝑟𝑘𝐵subscript21subscriptsuperscript𝑃tx𝑘subscript¯ℎ𝑘subscript𝑁0𝐵\displaystyle r_{k}=B\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{P^{\text{tx}}_{k}\bar{h}_{k}}{N_{0}B}\right), (15)

where B𝐵B is the allocated bandwidth, h¯ksubscript¯ℎ𝑘\bar{h}_{k} is the average channel gain between device k𝑘k and the BS during training111For future work, our approach can be extended to the case with instantaneous time-varying channels by considering a stochastic optimization formulation.222An important subject of future work here can be the integration of more advanced MIMO-based communication channels., Pktxsubscriptsuperscript𝑃tx𝑘P^{\text{tx}}_{k} is the transmit power of device k𝑘k, and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the power spectral density of white noise. After local training, device k𝑘k normalizes the model update as 𝒅tk/‖𝒅tk‖subscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑘𝑡normsubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{d}^{k}_{t}/||\boldsymbol{d}^{k}_{t}|| to match the predetermined quantization range [−1,1]11[-1,1]. Then, it transmits 𝒅tQ,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑄𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{d}^{Q,k}_{t} to the BS at given communication round t𝑡t. The transmission time Tksubscript𝑇𝑘T_{k} for uploading 𝒅tQ,ksubscriptsuperscript𝒅𝑄𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{d}^{Q,k}_{t} is given by

Tk​(m)=d​mrk.subscript𝑇𝑘𝑚𝑑𝑚subscript𝑟𝑘\displaystyle\displaystyle T_{k}(m)=\frac{dm}{r_{k}}. (16)

Then, the energy consumption for the uplink transmission is given by

EU​L,k​(m)=Tk​(m)×Pktx=Pktx​d​mB​log2⁡(1+Pktx​h¯kN0​B).superscript𝐸𝑈𝐿𝑘𝑚subscript𝑇𝑘𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑃tx𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑃tx𝑘𝑑𝑚𝐵subscript21subscriptsuperscript𝑃tx𝑘subscript¯ℎ𝑘subscript𝑁0𝐵\displaystyle E^{UL,k}(m)=T_{k}(m)\times P^{\text{tx}}_{k}=\frac{P^{\text{tx}}_{k}dm}{B\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{P^{\text{tx}}_{k}\bar{h}_{k}}{N_{0}B}\right)}. (17)

III Time and Energy efficient Federated QNN

Given our model, we now formulate a multi-objective optimization problem to minimize the energy consumption and the number of communication rounds while ensuring convergence under a target accuracy. We show that a tradeoff exists between the energy consumption and the number of communication rounds as a function of I𝐼I, K𝐾K, m𝑚m, and n𝑛n. For instance, we can reduce the amount of energy spent per iteration by using low precision and sampling a small number of devices. However, this slows the convergence rate because of quantization errors. Meanwhile, the system can allocate more bits and sample more devices to converge faster, i.e, to reduce the number of communication rounds, at the expense of spending more energy. However, this improvement becomes negligible after a certain threshold as shown later in the convergence analysis and simulations (see Theorem 1 and Section IV. Hence, finding the optimal solutions is important to balance this tradeoff and to achieve the target accuracy.

We aim to minimize both the expected total energy consumption and the number of communication rounds333Minimizing the total training time by considering the impact of quantization on the computation time can be an important subject of future research. until convergence under a target accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon as follows:

minI,K,m,nsubscript𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛\displaystyle\min_{I,K,m,n} [𝔼​[∑t=1T∑k∈𝒩tEU​L,k​(m)+I​EC,k​(n)],T]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑘subscript𝒩𝑡superscript𝐸𝑈𝐿𝑘𝑚𝐼superscript𝐸𝐶𝑘𝑛𝑇\displaystyle\quad\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{t}}E^{UL,k}(m)+IE^{C,k}(n)\right],T\right] (18a)
s.t. I∈[Imin,…,Imax],K∈[Kmin,…,N]formulae-sequence𝐼subscript𝐼min…subscript𝐼max𝐾subscript𝐾min…𝑁\displaystyle\quad I\in[I_{\text{min}},\dots,I_{\text{max}}],K\in[K_{\text{min}},\dots,N] (18b)
m∈[1,…,mmax],n∈[1,…,nmax]formulae-sequence𝑚1…subscript𝑚max𝑛1…subscript𝑛max\displaystyle\quad m\in[1,\dots,m_{\text{max}}],n\in[1,\dots,n_{\text{max}}] (18c)
𝔼​[F​(𝒘T)]−F​(𝒘∗)≤ϵ,𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝒘𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘italic-ϵ\displaystyle\quad\mathbb{E}[F(\boldsymbol{w}_{T})]-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\leq\epsilon, (18d)

where I𝐼I is the number of local iterations, Iminsubscript𝐼minI_{\text{min}} and Imaxsubscript𝐼maxI_{\text{max}} denote the minimum and maximum of I𝐼I, respectively, 𝔼​[F​(𝒘T)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝒘𝑇\mathbb{E}[F(\boldsymbol{w}_{T})] is the expectation of global loss function after T𝑇T communication rounds, F​(𝒘∗)𝐹superscript𝒘F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*}) is the minimum value of F𝐹F, and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the target accuracy. The possible values of I𝐼I and K𝐾K are given by (18b). Constraint (18c) represents the maximum precision levels in the transmission and the computation, respectively. Constraints (18d) captures the required number of communication rounds to achieve ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

This problem is challenging since the analytical expression of (18d) with respect to the control variables is unknown. Hence, it is not trivial to derive the exact number of T𝑇T to satisfy (18d). Quantization errors from local training and transmission will slow the convergence rate, thereby making achieving the target accuracy challenging. The convergence is also not always guaranteed under non-iid data distribution. Lastly, a global optimal solution, which minimizes each objective function simultaneously, is generally infeasible for a multi-objective optimization problem [22]. Therefore, a closed-form solution may not exist due to the tradeoff between two objectives.

To solve this problem, we first obtain the analytical relationship between (18d) and I,K,m𝐼𝐾𝑚I,K,m, and n𝑛n to derive T𝑇T with respect to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. As done in [23, 19, 10], we make the following assumptions on the loss function as follows

Assumption 1.

The loss function has the following properties

  • •

    Fk​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}) is L𝐿L-smooth: ∀for-all\forall 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v} and 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} Fk​(𝒗)≤Fk​(𝒘)+(𝒗−𝒘)T​∇Fk​(𝒘)+L2​‖𝒗−𝒘‖2subscript𝐹𝑘𝒗subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘superscript𝒗𝒘𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘𝐿2superscriptnorm𝒗𝒘2F_{k}(\boldsymbol{v})\leq F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w})+(\boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{w})^{T}\nabla F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w})+\frac{L}{2}||\boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{w}||^{2}

  • •

    Fk​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}) is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex: ∀for-all\forall 𝒗𝒗\boldsymbol{v} and 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} Fk​(𝒗)≥Fk​(𝒘)+(𝒗−𝒘)T​∇Fk​(𝒘)+μ2​‖𝒗−𝒘‖2subscript𝐹𝑘𝒗subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘superscript𝒗𝒘𝑇∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘𝜇2superscriptnorm𝒗𝒘2F_{k}(\boldsymbol{v})\geq F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w})+(\boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{w})^{T}\nabla F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w})+\frac{\mu}{2}||\boldsymbol{v}-\boldsymbol{w}||^{2}

  • •

    The variance of SG is bounded: 𝔼​[‖∇Fk​(𝒘tk,ξtk)−∇Fk​(𝒘tk)‖2]≤σk2,∀k=1,…,N.formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2for-all𝑘1…𝑁\mathbb{E}[||\nabla F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t},\xi^{k}_{t})-\nabla F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t})||^{2}]\leq\sigma_{k}^{2},\ \forall k=1,\dots,N.

  • •

    The squared norm of SG is bounded: 𝔼​[‖∇Fk​(𝒘tk,ξtk)‖2]≤G2,∀k=1,…,Nformulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝑘𝑡2superscript𝐺2for-all𝑘1…𝑁\mathbb{E}[||\nabla F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{k}_{t},\xi^{k}_{t})||^{2}]\leq G^{2},\ \forall k=1,\dots,N.

These assumptions hold for some practical loss functions. Such examples include logistic regression, l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} norm regularized linear regression, and softmax classifier [24]. Since we use the quantization in both local training and transmission, the quantization error negatively affects the accuracy and the convergence of our FL system. We next leverage the results of Lemma 1 so as to derive T𝑇T with respect to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Proof.

See Appendix -C. ∎

We can see that ψ1subscript𝜓1\psi_{1} is unavoidable because of the quantization in local training. We also observe that high precision levels for n𝑛n and m𝑚m can improve the convergence rate. In particular, we can decrease the quantization error related terms in ψ1subscript𝜓1\psi_{1} and ψ2subscript𝜓2\psi_{2} by increasing n𝑛n and m𝑚m. However, this improvement becomes negligible after a certain level since those terms decrease exponentially with respect to precision levels. For ΓΓ{\Gamma}, it quantifies the difference between the loss function at the global optimum Fk​(𝒘∗)subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝒘F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{*}) and the one at the local optimum Fk∗superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k}^{*}. Hence, we can see that the degree of non-iid ΓΓ{\Gamma} degrades the convergence rate. If we set n=nmax𝑛subscript𝑛maxn=n_{\text{max}} and m=mmax𝑚subscript𝑚maxm=m_{\text{max}}, we can approximately recover the result of [23] since the quantization error decays exponentially with respect to n𝑛n and m𝑚m. The convergence rate also increases with K𝐾K. However, all these improvements come at the cost of consuming more energy. We can also see that (19) has the sampling probabilities related term ∑k=1Npk2​σk2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}^{2}\sigma_{k}^{2} in its numerator. Therefore, we can further improve the convergence rate by optimizing pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} as follows

minp1,…,pN∑k=1Npk2​σk2,s.t.∑k=1Npk=1,pk≥0,∀k.formulae-sequencesubscriptsubscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2s.t.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘1subscript𝑝𝑘0for-all𝑘\displaystyle\min_{p_{1},...,p_{N}}\quad\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}^{2}\sigma_{k}^{2},\quad\text{s.t.}\quad\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}=1,p_{k}\geq 0,\forall k. (21)

Since the above problem is convex, we can use KKT condition to solve the problem. Then, the optimal sampling probabilities can be given by pk=1/σk2∑k=1N1/σk2.subscript𝑝𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2p_{k}=\frac{1/\sigma_{k}^{2}}{\sum_{k=1}^{N}1/\sigma_{k}^{2}}.

From Theorem 1, we can bound (19) using ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in (18d) as follows

where ⌈⋅⌉⋅\lceil\cdot\rceil is the smallest integer larger than or equal to the input. To guarantee the convergence, we change the constraint of n𝑛n in (18c) as n∈[nmin,…,nmax]𝑛subscript𝑛min…subscript𝑛maxn\in[n_{\text{min}},\dots,n_{\text{max}}]. Now, we express each objective function as function of the control variables using Theorem 1. For notational simplicity, we use g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) for the expected total energy consumption and g2​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{2}(I,K,m,n) for the number of communication rounds T𝑇T. Since each device k𝑘k is selected with probability pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}, ∀kfor-all𝑘\forall k, we can derive the expectation of the energy consumption in (18a) as follows

g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛\displaystyle g_{1}(I,K,m,n) =𝔼​[∑t=1T∑k∈𝒩tEU​L,k​(m)+I​EC,k​(n)]absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑘subscript𝒩𝑡superscript𝐸𝑈𝐿𝑘𝑚𝐼superscript𝐸𝐶𝑘𝑛\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{N}_{t}}E^{UL,k}(m)+IE^{C,k}(n)\right]

Next, we derive g2​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{2}(I,K,m,n) in a closed-form to fully express the objective functions and to remove the accuracy constraint (18d). For any feasible solution that satisfies (18d) with equality, we can always choose T0>Tsubscript𝑇0𝑇T_{0}>T such that T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} still satisfies (18d). Since such T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} will increase the value of the objectives, the accuracy constraint (18d) should be satisfied with equality [10]. Hence, we take equality in (22) to obtain:

g2​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛\displaystyle g_{2}(I,K,m,n) =β2​ψ2I​(β​μ−1)​(2​ϵL−β​ψ1β​μ−1)−γI.absentsuperscript𝛽2subscript𝜓2𝐼𝛽𝜇12italic-ϵ𝐿𝛽subscript𝜓1𝛽𝜇1𝛾𝐼\displaystyle=\frac{\beta^{2}\psi_{2}}{I(\beta\mu-1)(\frac{2\epsilon}{L}-\frac{\beta\psi_{1}}{\beta\mu-1})}-\frac{\gamma}{I}. (25)

Then, we can change the original problem as below

minI,K,m,n⁡[g1​(I,K,m,n),g2​(I,K,m,n)]s.t.(​18b​),(​18c​).subscript𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛s.t.italic-(18bitalic-)italic-(18citalic-)\displaystyle\min_{I,K,m,n}\left[g_{1}(I,K,m,n),g_{2}(I,K,m,n)\right]\quad\textrm{s.t.}\quad\eqref{I and K constraints},\eqref{m and n constraints}. (26a)

Since we have two conflicting objective functions, it is infeasible to find a global optimal solution to minimize each objective function simultaneously. Although introducing a weighted sum of the objective functions might provide a unique solution, its optimality is not always guaranteed. We also need to solve the problem again if those weights change. Hence, we instead consider the set of Pareto optimal points to obtain an efficient collection of solutions to minimize each objective function and capture the tradeoff. It is known that the set of all Pareto optimal points forms a Pareto boundary in two-dimensional space. Therefore, we use the so-called normal boundary inspection (NBI) method since it provides evenly distributed Pareto optimal points [25].

We first introduce some terminologies to facilitate the analysis. For a multi-objective function 𝒈​(𝒙)=[g1​(𝒙),g2​(𝒙),…​gM​(𝒙)]T𝒈𝒙superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝒙subscript𝑔2𝒙…subscript𝑔𝑀𝒙𝑇\boldsymbol{g}(\boldsymbol{x})=[g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}),g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x}),\dots g_{M}(\boldsymbol{x})]^{T} and a feasible set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, we define 𝒙i∗superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{*} as a global solution to minimize gi​(𝒙)subscript𝑔𝑖𝒙g_{i}(\boldsymbol{x}), i=1​…​M𝑖1…𝑀i=1\dots M, over 𝒙∈𝒞𝒙𝒞\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathcal{C}. Let 𝒈i∗=𝒈​(𝒙i∗)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑖𝒈superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖\boldsymbol{g}_{i}^{*}=\boldsymbol{g}(\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{*}) for i=1​…​M𝑖1…𝑀i=1\dots M, and we define the utopia point 𝒈∗superscript𝒈\boldsymbol{g}^{*}, which is composed of individual global minima 𝒈i∗superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑖\boldsymbol{g}_{i}^{*}. We define the M×M𝑀𝑀M\times M matrix ΦΦ\Phi, whose i𝑖ith column is 𝒈i∗−𝒈∗.superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝒈\boldsymbol{g}_{i}^{*}-\boldsymbol{g}^{*}. The set of the convex combinations of 𝒈i∗−𝒈∗superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑖superscript𝒈\boldsymbol{g}_{i}^{*}-\boldsymbol{g}^{*} such that {Φ​𝜻|ζi≥0​and​∑i=1Mζi=1}conditional-setΦ𝜻subscript𝜁𝑖0andsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝜁𝑖1\{\Phi\boldsymbol{\zeta}\ |\ \zeta_{i}\geq 0\ \text{and}\ \sum_{i=1}^{M}\zeta_{i}=1\} is defined as convex hull of individual minima (CHIM) [25]. For simplicity, we now use 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} to represent all feasible constraint sets (18b) - (18c). We also define 𝒙i∗superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{*} as (I,K,m,n)𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛(I,K,m,n) such that gi​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔𝑖𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{i}(I,K,m,n) can be minimized over 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} for i=1𝑖1i=1 and 222.

The basic premise of NBI is that any intersection points between the boundary of {𝒈(I,K,m,n)\{\boldsymbol{g}(I,K,m,n) ||| (I,K,m,n)∈𝒞}(I,K,m,n)\in\mathcal{C}\} and a vector pointing toward the utopia point emanating from the CHIM are Pareto optimal. We can imagine that the set of Pareto optimal points will form a curve connecting 𝒈​(𝒙1∗)=[g1​(𝒙1∗),g2​(𝒙1∗)]𝒈superscriptsubscript𝒙1subscript𝑔1superscriptsubscript𝒙1subscript𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝒙1\boldsymbol{g}(\boldsymbol{x}_{1}^{*})=[g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}_{1}^{*}),g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x}_{1}^{*})] and 𝒈​(𝒙2∗)=[g1​(𝒙2∗),g2​(𝒙2∗)]𝒈superscriptsubscript𝒙2subscript𝑔1superscriptsubscript𝒙2subscript𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝒙2\boldsymbol{g}(\boldsymbol{x}_{2}^{*})=[g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}_{2}^{*}),g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x}_{2}^{*})]. Hence, we first need to obtain 𝒙1∗superscriptsubscript𝒙1\boldsymbol{x}_{1}^{*} and 𝒙2∗superscriptsubscript𝒙2\boldsymbol{x}_{2}^{*}. In the next two subsections, we will minimize g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) and g2​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{2}(I,K,m,n) separately.

III-A Minimizing g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n)

Since 𝒙1∗superscriptsubscript𝒙1\boldsymbol{x}_{1}^{*} is a global solution to minimize g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n), we can find it solving:

minI,K,m,ng1​(I,K,m,n),s.t.(I,K,m,n)∈𝒞.subscript𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛s.t.𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛𝒞\displaystyle\min_{I,K,m,n}\quad g_{1}(I,K,m,n),\quad\textrm{s.t.}\quad(I,K,m,n)\in\mathcal{C}. (27a)

This problem is non-convex because the control variables are an integer and the constraints are not a convex set. For tractability, we relax the control variables as continuous variables. The relaxed variables will be rounded back to integers for feasibility. From (24) and (25), we can see that g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) is a linear function with respect to K𝐾K. Therefore, Kminsubscript𝐾minK_{\text{min}} always minimizes g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n). Moreover, the relaxed problem is convex with respect to I𝐼I since ∂2g1​(I,K,m,n)∂I2>0superscript2subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛superscript𝐼20\frac{\partial^{2}g_{1}(I,K,m,n)}{\partial I^{2}}>0. Hence, we can obtain the optimal I𝐼I to minimize g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) from the first derivative test as

where

Here, H1subscript𝐻1H_{1} and H3subscript𝐻3H_{3} express the cost of local training and the cost of transmission, respectively, while H2subscript𝐻2H_{2} depends on both of them. We next present a closed-form solution of the above equation from Cardano’s formula [26].

For given m𝑚m and n𝑛n, the optimal I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} to minimize g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) is given by

From Lemma 2, we can see that the value of I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} decreases due to the increased cost of local training H1subscript𝐻1H_{1} as we allocate a larger n𝑛n. Since the quantization error decreases as n𝑛n increases, a large I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} is not required. Hence, an FL system can decrease the value of I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} to reduce the increased local computation energy. We can also see that I′superscript𝐼′I^{\prime} increases as the cost of transmission H3subscript𝐻3H_{3} increases. Then, for convergence, the FL algorithm can perform more local iterations instead of frequently exchanging model parameters due to the increased communication overhead.

Although g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) is non-convex with respect to m𝑚m, there exists m′∈𝒞superscript𝑚′𝒞m^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C} such that for m≤m′𝑚superscript𝑚′m\leq m^{\prime}, g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) is non-increasing, and for m≥m′𝑚superscript𝑚′m\geq m^{\prime}, g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) is non-decreasing. This is because g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) decreases as the convergence rate becomes faster for increasing m𝑚m. Then, g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) increases after m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} due to unnecessarily allocated bits. Since g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) is differentiable at m𝑚m, we can find such local optimal m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} from ∂g1​(I,K,m,n)/∂m=0subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛𝑚0\partial g_{1}(I,K,m,n)/\partial m=0 using Fermat’s Theorem [4]. To obtain m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime}, we formulate the transcendental equation as below

∂g1​(I,K,m,n)∂msubscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛𝑚\displaystyle\frac{\partial g_{1}(I,K,m,n)}{\partial m} =0↔m=MA​22​m+MB,↔absent0𝑚subscript𝑀𝐴superscript22𝑚subscript𝑀𝐵\displaystyle=0\leftrightarrow m=M_{A}2^{2m}+M_{B}, (33)

where

We present a closed-form solution of the above equation in the following Lemma.

Lemma 3.

For given I𝐼I and n𝑛n, the local optimal m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime} to minimize g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) will be:

where W​(⋅)𝑊⋅W(\cdot) is the Lambert W𝑊W function.

Following the same logic of obtaining m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime}, we can find a local optimal solution n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} from the first derivative test. Although there is no analytical solution for n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime}, we can still obtain it numerically using a line search method. Then, problem (27a) can be optimized iteratively. We first obtain two analytical solutions for I𝐼I and m𝑚m. From these solutions, we numerically find a local optimal n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime}. Since g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) has a unique solution to each variable, it converges to a stationary point [27]. Although these points cannot guarantee to obtain globally Pareto optimal, using the NBI method, we are still guaranteed to reach locally Pareto optimal points [25]. In Section IV, we will also numerically show that the obtained points can still cover most of the practical portion of a global Pareto boundary. For ease of exposition, hereinafter, we refer to these local Pareto optimal points as “Pareto optimal”.

III-B Minimizing g2​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{2}(I,K,m,n)

Now, we obtain 𝒙2∗superscriptsubscript𝒙2\boldsymbol{x}_{2}^{*} from the following problem to complete finding the utopia point.

minI,K,m,ng2​(I,K,m,n),s.t.(I,K,m,n)∈𝒞.subscript𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛s.t.𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛𝒞\displaystyle\min_{I,K,m,n}\quad g_{2}(I,K,m,n),\quad\textrm{s.t.}\quad(I,K,m,n)\in\mathcal{C}. (36a)

From (25), the objective function is a decreasing function with respect to K,m𝐾𝑚K,m, and n𝑛n. We now obtain the Pareto boundary using NBI. Theorem 2.

For λi→∞→subscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i}\rightarrow\infty as i→∞→𝑖i\rightarrow\infty, solution 𝐱isuperscript𝐱𝑖\boldsymbol{x}^{i} approaches the global optimal solution of problem (43a), and it also becomes Pareto optimal.

III-D Nash Bargaining Solution

Since the solutions from (18a) are Pareto optimal, there is always an issue of choosing the best point. This is because any improvement on one objective function leads to the degradation of another. We can tackle this problem considering a bargaining process [29] between two players: one tries to minimize the energy consumption and another aims to reduce the number of communication rounds. Since the parameters of FL, i.e., (I,K,m,n)𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛(I,K,m,n), are shared, the players should reach a certain agreement over the parameters. It is known that NBS can be a unique solution to this bargaining process. The NBS was chosen here because it satisfies several fairness axioms [29], and thus, it has been used as a fair solution to resource management problems [30, 31]. We can obtain the NBS from the following problem [29]:

maxg1​(𝒙),g2​(𝒙)subscriptsubscript𝑔1𝒙subscript𝑔2𝒙\displaystyle\max_{g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}),g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x})} (g1​(𝑫)−g1​(𝒙))​(g2​(𝑫)−g2​(𝒙))subscript𝑔1𝑫subscript𝑔1𝒙subscript𝑔2𝑫subscript𝑔2𝒙\displaystyle\quad(g_{1}(\boldsymbol{D})-g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}))(g_{2}(\boldsymbol{D})-g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x}))
s.t. (g1​(𝒙),g2​(𝒙))∈gach¯,subscript𝑔1𝒙subscript𝑔2𝒙¯subscript𝑔ach\displaystyle\quad(g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}),g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x}))\in\overline{g_{\text{ach}}}, (47a)

where gach=∪𝒙∈𝒞​(g1​(𝒙),g2​(𝒙))subscript𝑔ach𝒙𝒞subscript𝑔1𝒙subscript𝑔2𝒙g_{\text{ach}}=\underset{\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathcal{C}}{\cup}\ (g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}),g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x})) is the achievable set of (g1​(𝒙),g2​(𝒙))subscript𝑔1𝒙subscript𝑔2𝒙(g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}),g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x})), gach¯¯subscript𝑔ach\overline{g_{\text{ach}}} represents the convex hull of gachsubscript𝑔achg_{\text{ach}}, and 𝑫𝑫\boldsymbol{D} is the outcome when the players fail to cooperate. Since the NBS always lies on the Pareto boundary, we perform the bargaining process on the obtained boundary from Algorithm 2. Then, we can find the NBS graphically by finding a tangential point where the boundary and a parabola (g1(𝑫)−g1(𝒙))(g2(𝑫)−g2(𝒙)=Δ(g_{1}(\boldsymbol{D})-g_{1}(\boldsymbol{x}))(g_{2}(\boldsymbol{D})-g_{2}(\boldsymbol{x})=\Delta intersects with constant ΔΔ\Delta.

IV Simulation Results and Analysis

For our simulations, unless stated otherwise, we uniformly deploy N=50𝑁50N=50 devices over a square area of size 500500500 m ×\times 500500500 m serviced by one BS at the center, and we assume a Rayleigh fading channel with a path loss exponent of 4. We assume that the FL algorithm is used for a classification task with MNIST dataset. We distribute the training dataset over devices in a non-iid fashion by allocating labels from a Dirichlet distribution with parameter 0.1. A softmax classifier is used to measure our FL performance. We also use Pktx=100subscriptsuperscript𝑃tx𝑘100P^{\text{tx}}_{k}=100 mW, B=10𝐵10B=10 MHz, N0=−173subscript𝑁0173N_{0}=-173 dBm, S=2𝑆2S=2 MB, xin=786subscript𝑥in786x_{\text{in}}=786, mmax=32subscript𝑚max32m_{\text{max}}=32 bits, nmax=32subscript𝑛max32n_{\text{max}}=32 bits, Imin=1subscript𝐼min1I_{\text{min}}=1, Imax=30subscript𝐼max30I_{\text{max}}=30, Kmin=1subscript𝐾min1K_{\text{min}}=1, ϵ=0.1italic-ϵ0.1\epsilon=0.1, ρ=100𝜌100\rho=100, and γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1, ∀k=1,…,Nfor-all𝑘1…𝑁\forall k=1,\dots,N. For L𝐿L, we used the reported value L=0.097𝐿0.097L=0.097 with the same dataset and the loss function [32]. However, estimating μ𝜇\mu is more challenging than the estimation of L𝐿L. Since the value of μ𝜇\mu is widely assumed to be a small value between [0.001,1]0.0011[0.001,1] [33][34], we used μ=0.05𝜇0.05\mu=0.05 as done in [34] with the same dataset. We assume that each device trains a QNN structure with five convolutional layers and three fully-connected layers. Specifically, the convolutional layers consist of 128 kernels of size 3 × 3, two of 64 kernels of size 3×3, and two of 32 kernels of size 3x3. The first layer is followed by 3x3 pooling and the second and the fifth layer are followed by 3x3 max pooling with a stride of two. Then, we have one dense layer of 2000 neurons, one fully-connected layer of 100 neurons, and the output layer. In this setting, we have Nc=0.0405×109,d=0.41×106formulae-sequencesubscript𝑁𝑐0.0405superscript109𝑑0.41superscript106N_{c}=0.0405\times 10^{9},d=0.41\times 10^{6}, and Os=4990.subscript𝑂𝑠4990O_{s}=4990. To estimate G𝐺G and σksubscript𝜎𝑘\sigma_{k}, we measure every device’s average maximum norm of stochastic gradients Gksubscript𝐺𝑘G_{k} for the initial 20 local iterations and set G=maxk⁡Gk𝐺subscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑘G=\max_{k}\ G_{k}, ∀k={1,…,N}.for-all𝑘1…𝑁\forall k=\{1,\dots,N\}. We used the same gradients information to estimate σksubscript𝜎𝑘\sigma_{k} while measuring Gksubscript𝐺𝑘G_{k}. Since the norm of the stochastic gradient generally decreases with training epochs, we use the initial values of Gksubscript𝐺𝑘G_{k} to estimate G𝐺G as in [35]. Similarly, since loss functions are in general decreasing with training epoch, we can bound ΓΓ{\Gamma} as Γ=∑k=1Npk​(Fk​(𝒘∗)−Fk∗)≤∑k=1Npk​Fk​(𝒘∗)≤∑k=1Npk​Fk​(𝒘′)Γsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝒘superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝒘′{\Gamma}=\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}(F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})-F_{k}^{*})\leq\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\leq\sum_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}F_{k}(\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}), where 𝒘′superscript𝒘′\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime} can be a global model in early stage. From the above setting, we estimated G=0.25𝐺0.25G=0.25. We then used the global model, which was used to measure G𝐺G, to estimate Γ=0.6Γ0.6{\Gamma}=0.6. For the computing model, we use a 282828 nm technology processing chip and set A=3.7𝐴3.7A=3.7 pJ, Ad=150subscript𝐴𝑑150A_{d}=150, and α=1.25𝛼1.25\alpha=1.25 as done in [20]. For the disagreement point 𝑫𝑫\boldsymbol{D}, we use (Imax,1,1,nmin)subscript𝐼max11subscript𝑛min(I_{\text{max}},1,1,n_{\text{min}}) as this setting is neither biased towards minimizing the energy consumption nor towards the number of communication rounds. We assume that each device has the same architecture of the processing chip. All statistical results are averaged over a number of independent runs.

Figure 3 shows the Pareto boundary from Algorithm 2 as well as the feasible area obtained from the exhaustive search for N=50𝑁50N=50. We can see that our boundary and the actual Pareto boundary match well. Although we cannot find the global Pareto optimal points due to the non-convexity of problem (27a), it is clear that our analysis can still cover most of the important points that can effectively show the tradeoff in the feasible region.

Figure 4 and Table II(a) show the Pareto boundaries obtained from the Algorithm 2 and the solutions of four possible operating points, respectively, for varying N𝑁N. Each solution represents (I,K,m,n)𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛(I,K,m,n), where I𝐼I is the number of local iterations, K𝐾K is the number of sampled devices, m𝑚m is the precision level for transmission, and n𝑛n is the precision level for local training. SUM represents the point that minimizes the sum of the two objectives. We can obtain the SUM by finding a tangential point between the Pareto boundary and the line g1​(I,K,m,n)+g2​(I,K,m,n)=Δsubscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛Δg_{1}(I,K,m,n)+g_{2}(I,K,m,n)=\Delta with Δ∈ℝΔℝ\Delta\in\mathbb{R} using a bisection algorithm. Eminsubscript𝐸minE_{\text{min}} and Tminsubscript𝑇minT_{\text{min}} are the solutions that separately optimize g1​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔1𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{1}(I,K,m,n) and g2​(I,K,m,n)subscript𝑔2𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛g_{2}(I,K,m,n), respectively. From Fig. 4, we can see that the energy consumption increases while the number of communication rounds decreases to achieve the target accuracy for increasing N𝑁N. The FL system can choose more devices at each communication round as N𝑁N increases. Hence, the impact of SG variance decreases as shown in Theorem 1. Since involving more devices in the averaging process implies an increase in the size of the batch, the convergence rate increases by using more energy [36].

From Table II(a) and Fig. 4, we can see that NBS points are more biased toward reducing the energy consumption while the SUM points focus on minimizing communication rounds. We can also see that, as N𝑁N becomes larger, the optimal I𝐼I decreases while K𝐾K increases. This is because I𝐼I is a decreasing function with respect to G𝐺G as shown in Lemmas 2 and 4. Hence, the FL system decreases I𝐼I to avoid model discrepancy over devices since the estimated value of G𝐺G becomes larger for increasing N𝑁N. However, a small I𝐼I will slow down the process to reach optimal weights in the local training. To mitigate this, the FL system then increases K𝐾K so that it can obtain more information in the averaging process by selecting more devices.

Figure 5 and Table II(b) present the Pareto boundaries from the Algorithm 2 and the corresponding solutions when increasing the size of the neural networks. We keep the same structure of our default CNN, but we now increase the number of neurons in the convolutional and fully-connected layers. For each CNN model, the number of parameters will be 0.27×106,0.41×106,0.27superscript1060.41superscript1060.27\times 10^{6},0.41\times 10^{6}, and 1.61×1061.61superscript1061.61\times 10^{6}, respectively. Fig. 5 and Table II(b) show that the energy consumption and the number of communication rounds until convergence increase with the model size. For CNN3, the energy cost increased significantly since its large model size cannot be fit into the SRAM even after quantization. From Table II(b), we can see that the FL system requires higher precision levels for larger neural networks. This is because the quantization error increases for larger neural networks, as per Lemma 1. Hence, the FL system allocates more bits for both the computation and the transmission so as to mitigate the quantization error. This, in turn, means that the use of larger neural networks will naturally require more energy, even if the neural network is quantized.

Figure 6(a) presents the impact of target accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon on the optimal precision level n𝑛n and the performance. We can see that as target accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon increases, the optimal precision level n𝑛n also increases to achieve the convergence. This is because quantization in local training yields the unavoidable term ψ1subscript𝜓1\psi_{1} as shown in Theorem 1. Hence, to achieve a higher target accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, we need to allocate more precision level n𝑛n for local training to achieve the convergence. However, this can increase the number of DRAM accesses to fetch model parameters due to the increased memory size. Since the DRAM access energy is much larger than the MAC operation energy, the energy consumption may increase significantly. In Fig. 6(b), we can see that we need much more energy and communication rounds to achieve a higher target accuracy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

In Fig. 7, we show the performance of the NBS and the SUM points with increasing K𝐾K. We can see that the required communication rounds decrease as K𝐾K increases for both schemes. Hence, we can improve the convergence rate by increasing K𝐾K at the expense of more energy. This corroborates the analysis in Section III-A, which shows the total energy consumption is linear with respect to K𝐾K. Similarly, it also corroborates the fact that the required number of communication rounds to achieve a certain ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is a decreasing function of K𝐾K, i.e., 𝒪​(1K)𝒪1𝐾\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{K}), in Section III-B. However, we can see that this improvement is not much beneficial [23] as it linearly increases the energy consumption.

Figure 8 shows the required energy and communication rounds to achieve ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon using the NBS points. For FedAvg [4], we use (2,5,32,32)253232(2,5,32,32). FedPaq algorithm [37] uses periodic averaging, partial client participation, and quantization in transmission. Hence, we only optimize m𝑚m and use the same setting as FedAvg. iFedAvg scheme is proposed in [10], and it optimizes (I,K)𝐼𝐾(I,K) while data is represented in full-precision. UnifiedQ is a baseline introduced in the work in [15], and it optimizes (I,n)𝐼𝑛(I,n). We use m=16𝑚16m=16 as done in [15]. Here, we set K=5𝐾5K=5 for a fair comparison while the original version sampled whole devices at each round. For mnFedAvg, we only optimize (m,n)𝑚𝑛(m,n) with (I,K)=(2,5)𝐼𝐾25(I,K)=(2,5). All optimal parameters of the baselines are obtained from solving (18a). From Figs. 8a and 8b, we can see that our algorithm is the most efficient because it consumes the least energy and converges faster than other baselines to achieve ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. This is because we optimize all system parameters (I,K,m,n)𝐼𝐾𝑚𝑛(I,K,m,n) simultaneously. From Baseline 1 and 2, we observe that quantization during transmission is beneficial to save the energy, and it does not significantly affect the convergence rate. In particular, we can achieve around 70% of energy savings compared to FedAvg and around 16% of energy savings compared to UnifiedQ.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we have studied the problem of energy-efficient quantized FL over wireless networks. We have presented the energy model for our FL based on the physical structure of a processing chip considering the quantization. Then, we have formulated a multi-objective optimization problem to minimize the energy consumption and the number of communication rounds simultaneously under a target accuracy by controlling the number of local iterations, the number of selected users, the precision levels for the transmission, and the training. To solve this problem, we first have derived the convergence rate of our quantized FL. Based on it, we have used the NBI method to obtain the Pareto boundary. We also have derived analytical solutions that can optimize each objective function separately. Simulation results have validated our theoretical analysis and provided design insights with two practical operating points. We have also shown that our model requires much less energy than a standard FL model and the baselines to achieve the convergence. In essence, this work provides the first systematic study on how to optimally design quantized FL balancing the tradeoff between energy efficiency and convergence rate, and the target accuracy over wireless networks.

-C Proof of Theorem 1

Since we use quantization in both local training and transmission, we cannot directly use the result of [23] to derive the convergence rate due to the quantization errors. We first define an additional auxiliary variable as done in [19] to prove Theorem 1 as below

Then, we can obtain Theorem 1 from L𝐿L - smoothness of the loss function using 𝔼​[F​(𝒘¯t+1)−F​(𝒘∗)]≤L2​𝔼​[‖𝒘¯t+1−𝒘∗‖]2𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript¯𝒘𝑡1𝐹superscript𝒘𝐿2𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]normsubscript¯𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘2\mathbb{E}[F(\bar{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})]\leq\frac{L}{2}\mathbb{E}\left[||\bar{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{w}^{*}||\right]^{2}. Finally, we change the time scale to local iteration.
